content: The Act may be cited as the "Technology Retraining and Investment Now Act for the 21st Century". The Congress finds that the value added by workers in the US and other countries is increasingly dependent on educational and training investments. The investment in knowledge workers by US trading partners exceeds that of the US government. The training of knowledge workers in other countries exceeds the investment made by the US government. This has led to a decline in educational performance in the US compared to other countries, making it challenging for US businesses to fund worker education in a global marketplace. The global workforce environment puts pressure on US companies to use highly educated workers from other countries. It is crucial for the US government to reverse this trend to support national security, the middle class, and workers' welfare while remaining competitive globally. The US government aims to reverse the trend of relying on highly educated foreign workers to support national security, the middle class, and workers' welfare while maintaining global competitiveness. Public-private partnerships, like the research and development tax credit, help maximize sector strengths, reduce development risk, and improve cost effectiveness. Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 emphasizes maximizing sector strengths, reducing development risk, and improving cost effectiveness. Businesses play a crucial role in training the workforce for available jobs and developing new training methods. With a significant number of baby boomers retiring in the next 20 years, the US must ensure it can train its workforce for high-paying jobs. The United States must train its workforce for high-paying information and communications technology jobs to support retiring baby boomers. The Act aims to encourage businesses and individuals to support educational development. The Act aims to encourage businesses and individuals to support the educational development of knowledge workers in the United States by providing incentives for information and communications technology education and training investments. The Act aims to encourage businesses to invest in training for skills in various professions to expand and maintain their businesses effectively. SEC. 30D. Information and Communications Technology Education and Training Program Expenses. The text chunk discusses the allowance of a tax credit for information and communications technology education and training program expenses incurred by taxpayers for the benefit of employees or individuals. The credit is equal to 50 percent of the expenses paid. The tax credit is allowable to the employer for expenses incurred for the benefit of employees or individuals, with a limitation of $4,000 per individual for the taxable year. The tax credit for employer expenses is limited to $4,000 per individual for the taxable year, with a potential increase to $5,000 for certain programs and individuals. The tax credit for employer expenses is limited to $4,000 per individual for the taxable year, potentially increasing to $5,000 for specific programs and individuals, such as those in empowerment zones, enterprise communities, or renewal communities. In a rural enterprise community designated under section 766 of the Agriculture, Rural Development, Food and Drug Administration, and Related Agencies Appropriations Act, 1999. In a Rural Economic Area Partnership Zone designated by the Secretary of Agriculture or in an area under the jurisdiction of an Indian tribal government, or by an employer with 200 or fewer employees. In an Indian tribal government jurisdiction or by an employer with 200 or fewer employees, the Information Technology Education and Training Program Expenses are defined for individuals with disabilities. The term 'information technology education and training program expenses' refers to costs incurred for participating in an IT education and training program, including coursework and certification testing. Expenses for participating in information and communications technology education and training programs include course work, certification testing, programs registered by the Department of Labor, and other essential skill assessment expenses. Expenses for information technology education and training programs include course work, certification testing, and essential skill assessment expenses. These programs are provided in the United States by accredited institutions. The curr_chunk discusses information technology education and training programs provided in the United States by accredited institutions, commercial information technology training providers, and employer-owned training organizations. The curr_chunk defines a commercial information technology training provider as a private sector organization offering ICT education and training programs. It also explains an employer-owned information technology training organization as a private sector entity providing IT training to employees using internal resources. The company provides IT training to employees using internal resources and industry-recognized methods. No other deductions or credits are allowed for expenses covered by this training program. The credit under this section is reduced by expenses for IT education and training programs. Rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52 apply. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the excess of certain rules. The credit under this section is subject to rules similar to section 45A(e)(2) and subsections (c), (d), and (e) of section 52. The credit allowed for any taxable year cannot exceed the excess of the regular tax reduced by certain credits over the tentative minimum tax for the year. "Sec. 30D. Information and communications technology education and training program expenses. Effective Date: Amendments apply to expenses incurred after December 31, 2006. SEC. 4. ELIGIBLE EDUCATIONAL INSTITUTION." The term 'eligible educational institution' is defined as an institution described in the Higher Education Act of 1965 and eligible to participate in a program under title IV of such Act. The amendment expands the definition of 'eligible educational institution' to include commercial information and communications technology training providers. Additionally, a conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The effective date for these amendments is for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2006. SEC. 5. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY TRAINING CERTIFICATION ADVISORY BOARD. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board, established by the Secretary of the Treasury, consists of up to seven members associated with IT certification and training organizations. The Board must meet at least annually and elect a Chairperson from its members. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board must meet at least annually and elect a Chairperson from its members who is a member of an information technology industry trade association. The Board is responsible for developing guidelines for computer science and information technology courses, as well as a list of qualifying information technology training and certifications for tax credits. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board is responsible for developing guidelines for computer science and information technology courses, as well as a list of qualifying information technology training and certifications for tax credits. The Board must submit this list to the Secretary of the Treasury annually. Members of the Board serve without compensation and are reimbursed for travel expenses. The Information Technology Training Certification Advisory Board members serve without compensation but are reimbursed for travel expenses. Section 14(b) of the Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Board.
